awd_titl_txt: ATD: Forecasting Threats due to Polarization Using Spatio-Temporal Topic Flows
awd_abstract_narration:
Information warfare and the purposeful spread of disinformation threatens to destabilize democratic processes by polarizing the population and depleting social capital. Information diffusion on social media is an important means by which polarization increases and spreads through society.  In this project, the investigators will address the following fundamental question: How do we measure, predict and mitigate the insidious threats resulting from extreme polarization due to information diffusion on social media?

The investigators will build real-time algorithmic threat forecasting based on information diffusion patterns using topic flow modeling, primarily, of Twitter data. The investigators will extend the popular Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) model to include spatio-temporal diffusion terms. The investigators will use this to build a 'polarization barometer' based on sentiment analysis of the data. The investigators will implement Bayesian inferential algorithms capturing essential features of the spatio-temporal information flows and link these quantitative results to the sociological concept of social capital.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored the modeling of textual data to understand the processes of polarization in civil society in the United States. It uses sentiment analysis and adapts the Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) model (more precisely, the Structural Topic Model) with entropy scores to create a topic-specific polarization timeseries. Using historical newspaper articles data from NewsBank, we analyze various time periods to study how polarization has changed over time and across space.

Polarization in civil society is not a new phenomenon. Researchers have studies both the causes of polarization (e.g., politics, social issues) and its effects (e.g., creation of echo chambers, physical violence). We propose an algorithmic process to study polarization as exemplified by widely differing viewpoints on the same topic. Since, much of the data that reflects polarization is textual in nature, we leverage existing text analytic tools like sentiment analysis, topic modeling etc. to create a model that identifies polarization.

Specifically, we are interested in polarization that persists in time and that may have direct effects on society. We use newspaper articles across time and different spatial locations to quantify polarization in a number of different topics such as politics, crime, sports, international affairs etc. Examining news articles from multiple decades also allows us to account for different writing paradigms. Polarization in each of these topics is defined as an entropy score on the sentiment expressed in that topic across multiple articles aggregated across days. This is achieved by first building a topic model using the LDA algorithm across the corpus of news articles, identifying the sentiment for each article based on sentiment analysis, assigning topic sentiments based on topic distributions across multiple articles. Based on the distribution of these topic sentiments, we create an entropy score that identifies how the topic sentiment is distributed - a topic that has articles with both positive and negative sentiments in equal measure is identified by the algorithm as being a polarizing topic.

The database NewsBank (maintained by NewsBank Inc.), provides access to newspaper articles published in various local and national newspapers. We use a curated subset from this database to study historical patterns of polarization. Specifically, we consider different types of events that were theorized to be "non-polarizing" and ?polarizing.?  We consider articles written around the time of various Olympics as examples of ?non-polarizing? events, and we use these for baselining our polarization models. In contrast, articles written around the times of presidential elections are predicted to be ?polarizing? events.  Compared to our baseline, these events show higher polarization scores. In each of these time periods, we also identify topics such as crime (largely non-polarizing but persistent across time), sports (polarizing locally but not persistent across time), international affairs (mix of both polarizing and non-polarizing but not persistent across time) etc. to identify different aspects of polarization in the news. A study of these timeseries shows interesting patterns as to how polarization has changed across time, and how it varies across different topics. These insights supplement anecdotal research performed by sociologists (including co-PI James Hawdon) on polarization.

Using the algorithms developed in the course of this project, we believe that researchers can build an automated tool that will provide insights as to how polarization changes over time. Correlating the polarization measure to various socio-economic variables will provide insights into the causes and effects of polarization that are of interest to sociologists, political scientists, economists etc. Studying this process using different text data corpuses such as Twitter, Facebook etc. will provide insights into real-time diffusion trends across space and variations across time. Algorithmic improvements will help develop new means of handling large text data for corpora that are non-stationary in time and topics.
